user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_addr_to_key:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
MHD_ip_addr_to_key (const struct sockaddr_storage *addr,
                    socklen_t addrlen,
                    struct MHD_IPCount *key)
{
  memset (key,
          0,
          sizeof(*key));

  /* IPv4 addresses */
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    if (AF_INET == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv4,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in *) addr)->sin_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in *) NULL)->sin_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }

#ifdef HAVE_INET6
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in6) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    /* IPv6 addresses */
    if (AF_INET6 == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET6;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv6,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) addr)->sin6_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) NULL)->sin6_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }
#endif

  /* Some other address */
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_ip_addr_to_key:

...

...
#define HAVE_INET6 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expression in the provided function is manifestly invariant. The selection statements present are: 1) if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in) <= (size_t) addrlen) — sizeof(...) is a compile-time constant but the condition depends on the runtime parameter addrlen, so it is not invariant. 2) if (AF_INET == addr->ss_family) — depends on the runtime value addr->ss_family. 3) #ifdef HAVE_INET6 is a preprocessor conditional (evaluated at translation time), not a C controlling expression governed by MISRA Rule 14.3. 4) if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in6) <= (size_t) addrlen) and if (AF_INET6 == addr->ss_family) — analogous to the IPv4 checks and depend on runtime values. The memcpy/memset/return statements are not controlling expressions. The only compile-time constants (sizeof(...) and the AF_* macros) are used in comparisons with runtime values or in sizeof operands; thus none of the selection/iteration controlling expressions are invariant and require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Therefore there are no suspicious code fragments to report.
